poem.title: Ensnared_Deer
poem.introduction: These poems are transcribed from the work of Francisco X. Alarcón, Snake Poems, a collection of translations and responses to traditional Aztec poems, and are in the original Nahuatl with Alarcón's translation into English. The poems themselves come from the work of Ruiz de Alarcón, Tratado de las supersticiones y costumbres gentílicas que oy viven entre los indios naturales desta Nueva Espana, a treatise on the superstitions and customs of the natives of New Spain, which dates from 1629. http://www.plu.edu/~friesjj/poems/home.html

translation.l: spirit Seven Flower desert dweller it's all over with you're a goner in the night
where is Seven Flower where is he?
and his luck? ha ha! he was taken it's all over with
tlamazcaqui Chicome-Xochitl teotalhua ye iuhqui otititlanihuac yohualli
ca opatoloc ho ho! tlamaloc ye iuhqui
